column4: hi.. i installed some libraries in order to compile a program from source... but i don't remember the names of the libraries and i don't need them anymore.... is there a way to automatically remove them?
deborphan/debfoster but you have to be careful what you remove
how does that fidn the packages?
they go through every package on your system and ask you if you want to keep it
but if you keep ubuntu-desktop all dependencies of ubuntu-desktop will be marked as kept automatically so it isn't as bad as it sounds
how will that help me? i don't know which libraries i need still and which ones i don't
and so on with other packages, keeping banshee will keep the mono stack, etc
You end up having to decide on about 100 packages
i'm confused though.. if i don't know what packages i chose to install nor which packages the machine needed, how will i decide?
It'll keep the ones you need
If you say you want to keep ubuntu-desktop installed it'll know not to ask about anything that depends on
If you say you want to keep banshee it'll keep everything it depends on, etc
i just feel like when it comes upgrade time, i end up upgrading so many packages via the Internet because i don't uninstall enough things i don't need
you mostly have to tell it what apps you want
I run these tools at the end of every development cycle to clean up
best part: it remembers your choices for next time
tell it you want to keep ubuntu-desktop and next time you run it it won't even ask you
